courses.subject: MEDF
courses.title: Foundation Course for Health Sciences I (for MBChB only)
courses.description: This course introduces students to the foundation knowledge of biochemistry and molecular biology, including cellular processes and molecular aspects of cells and tissues in the human body, before they embark on the journey of Health Sciences II to get an overview of the human physiological functions. Topics in this course range from introducing the ingredients of life and biomolecules, mechanisms of membrane transport and cellular transport, cellular events leading to energy production, cell cycle and its regulation, overview of cell signaling and its relationship with neurotransmission and drug responses, to basic blood components and the biology of blood cells. Selected topics would be supplemented by case studies to review the relevance of these concepts to medical conditions or their applications.
courses.component:
Exercise
Independent Study
Lecture
Others
Project
Interactive Tutorial
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:

1. describe the roles of biomolecules in cellular processes and how they help to maintain the normal functions of a cell; and
2. recognize the importance of membrane transport, cellular transport and cell signaling to aid in different cellular functions, which serve the functional basis of tissues, organs, and body systems.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Lecture Topics**

• The ingredients of life

• Amino acids and proteins: multi-functional biomolecules

• Biocatalyst

• Carbohydrate and carbohydrate-containing biomolecules

• Lipid and its derivatives in human body

• Micronutrients: vitamins and minerals

• Bioenergetics and principles of metabolism

• Cell organelles and membrane transport

• Cellular transport and cytoskeleton

• DNA replication, cell cycle and programmed cell death

• Cell signaling and cellular response

• The biology of blood cells

* *Tutorials**

• Structure-function relationship of proteins

• Enzymes

• Cell cycle, apoptosis and cancer
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of each subject.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussions with the class representatives.
courses.required_readings: All textbooks as listed on the Faculty website.
courses.recommended_readings: All recommended references as listed on the Faculty website.

courses.subject: MEDF
courses.title: Foundation Course for Health Sciences I
courses.description: The human body can be studied through its levels of organization, with each level representing different features of life. In particular, the cellular and molecular levels enable us to appreciate how excitable cells such as neurons communicate within the human body by utilizing electrical voltages created by the movement of electrolytes across cell membranes. The generation of these micro-voltages is an important functional basis of various organ systems, such as the nervous system and the cardiovascular system. In physiology, one of the primary ions of electrolytes is the sodium ion, which plays essential roles in determining plasma osmolality, water balance and even blood pressure. In this foundation course, students will learn various aspects of basic science and organ-specific human physiology essential for an understanding of how the human body functions. Students are exposed to important concepts from both the chemical and physical sciences, which they then relate to human cell and organ functions.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:

1. describe general functions of plasma membrane and different cell organelles.
2. describe four physical processes of heat transfer, and relate them to the body and the mechanism of body temperature control.
3. describe different types of ion channels and protein pumps involved in the generation of action potential and maintenance of membrane excitability.
4. describe the general structure and function of a chemical synapse.
5. review the general organization of the nervous system and appreciate the importance of homeostatic control system.
6. distinguish electrolytes and non-electrolytes in body fluid and describe briefly how osmolality and selective permeability of cell membrane are important in determining water balance.
7. review the general physiology of the cardiovascular system in the control of mean arterial pressure.
8. identify major chemical and physiological buffering systems in the human body.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture Topics:

* The ingredients of life
* Cell organelles and cell membrane
* The electrochemical signals of excitable cells
* Integration of signals and body control: Nervous system
* Heat, energy and body temperature
* Flow, pressure and elasticity
* Body circulation: Cardio-vascular system
* Water, electrolytes and body fluid compartments
* Acids and bases
* Auto-marking exercises or quizzes (topic-specific)
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course adopts a number of formal and informal measures to generate feedback for evaluation about the course. Students or class representatives are encouraged to collate views during and at the end of the course. Another means of evaluation encourages students to use the Course and Teacher Evaluation (CTE). Students are also welcomed to give their feedback via email exchange, individual meeting, etc. Online surveys will also be provided to evaluate the effectiveness of e-learning in this course.
courses.required_readings: * *Basic Concepts in Biomedical Sciences I,** CUHK – CUSTOM, Taylor and Francis (2015) (ISBN: 9781138181939)
courses.recommended_readings: * *Vander's Human Physiology: The Mechanisms of Body Function.** Eric P. Widmaier, Hershel Raff, Kevin T. Strang. (15th Ed.) Mcgraw Hill Education. (ISBN: 978-1-259-08082-1)

courses.subject: MEDF
courses.title: Foundation Course for Health Sciences II
courses.description: This is an integrated course covering the structural, physiological and molecular aspects of cells and tissues in the human body. It provides a solid foundation upon which students can embark onto the full-fledged Medical, Nursing, Pharmacy, Chinese Medicine and Biotechnology, Entrepreneurship and Healthcare Management curriculum.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEC1920 or PHPC1001

courses.subject: MEDF
courses.title: Public Health and Healthcare Ethics
courses.description: This course will introduce undergraduate students to healthcare issues and challenges facing our society in the 21st century. The study of public health and healthcare ethics related themes will include history of modern medicine and public health, current global health issues, professionalism and various approaches to ethical reasoning that enable students to address the moral concerns related to public health and healthcare challenges. The various academic disciplines within the domains of public health will be introduced through case presentations of various global public health issues including COVID-19, SARS, air pollution, healthcare safety, health equity, health demography, obesity and non-communicable diseases followed by experience sharing by eminent health professionals.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEC1920 or PHPC1001
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, student should be able to:

* describe and articulate current global public health problems and their determinants
* describe the complexities of issues encountered in healthcare settings and the importance of professionalism
* apply bioethical principles and theories in analyzing contemporary public health problems
* demonstrate ethical arguments in a logical and coherent manner
courses.course_syllabus:
* An introduction to public health
* Ethical principles in public health and healthcare – Public health justice
* Public Health Problem: Infectious disease
* Ethics: Ethical approaches, decision-making framework, and patients’ autonomy
* Ethics: Professional ethics- our guide to professional conduct
* Ethics: Non-maleficence & beneficence – Quality of care & patient safety
* Hong Kong Health System Public Health Problem: Lifestyles and non-communicable diseases
* Public Health Problem: Pollution (Case study in environmental problems: the case of air pollution in Hong Kong)
* Social Determinants of Health
* The Frontiers of Public Health (Current Challenges & Global Health)
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the course.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussions with the class representatives.
courses.required_readings:
1. Beauchamp, T. L., & Childress, J. F. Principles of biomedical ethics (6th ed.) 2009. New York: Oxford University Press.
2. Griffiths S, Hill A, Gillian S. Public Health and Primary Care, New York, USA: Oxford University Press; 2007
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Beauchamp, T. L., & Childress, J. F. Principles of biomedical ethics (6th ed.). New York: Oxford University Press, 2009.
2. Griffiths S, Hill A, Gillian S. Public Health and Primary Care, New York, USA: Oxford University Press; 2007
3. Leung, GM and Bacon-Shone, JH (Eds.). Hong Kong's health system: Reflections, perspectives and visions. Hong Kong: Hong Kong University Press. 2006
4. Detels R, et al. (2011) Oxford Textbook of Public Health (5th ed.) Link: <https://oxfordmedicine.com/view/10.1093/med/9780199218707.001.0001/med-9780199218707-chapter-0101>
5. Marmot M, Wilkinson RG. Social Determinants of Health (2nd edition). UK: Oxford University Press; 2011
6. Rose G. Rose's Strategy of Preventive Medicine. Oxford University Press, 2008.
7. Rose, G. A. (Geoffrey Arthur) et al. Rose's Strategy of Preventive Medicine the Complete Original Text. New ed. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2008. Print.
8. Pol LG, Thomas R. The Demography of Health and Healtcare (3rd edition). Springer Dordrecht, 2013.

courses.subject: MEDF
courses.title: Communication Skills
courses.description: Course overview:To understand the basic theories of communication and appreciate the importance of effective communication.
courses.component:
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
Web-enhanced Teaching
Workshop
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

1. describe the basic theories of communication.
2. apply knowledge of communication for professional development.
3. introduce effective interpersonal communication skills for health professionals and the general public.
4. examine and utilize appropriate means of media for effective communication.
5. analyze and give constructive feedback to peers’ presentation.
courses.course_syllabus:
| Lectures (12 hours): | | | | --- | --- | | **Topic** | **Contents/ fundamental concepts** | | Introduction to communication | Communication etiquette Communication breakdown and management Basic communication theories Factors influencing interpersonal communication Effective reflective essay writing skills | | Effective Presentation Skills | Elements of a presentation Guidelines to effective individual and group presentations | | Communicating with clients | Communicating with clients across the lifespan Therapeutic communication skills Profession client helping relationship | | Communicating with health care professionals | Effective communication skills with health care professional | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
courses.feedback_evaluation: The course adopts a number of formal and informal measures to generate feedback for evaluation about the course. Students are encouraged to use the CU eLearning System and email to post their views, and class representatives are invited to collate the views of students during and at the end of the course. Another means of evaluation is using Course Teaching Evaluation (CTE) to evaluate the course. Students will provide quantitative and qualitative feedback on the whole course and on the teacher using a faculty-wide standardized questionnaire.
courses.recommended_readings:
(1) Books
• Capehart, K. D. (2020). Patient communication: getting the most out of that one-on-one time. In T. L. Schwinghammer, J. M. Koehler, J. S. Borchert, D. Slain & S. K. Park (Eds.). (11th ed.). Pharmacotherapy casebook: a patient-focused approach (ch. 3). McGraw-Hill Education. 〔electronic resource〕
• Dainton, M., & Zelley, E. D. (2019). Applying communication theory for professional life: A practical introduction (4th ed.). Sage Publications.
• DeVito, J. A. (2017). Essentials of Human Communication (9th ed.). Pearson.
• Griffin, C. L. & Bone, J. E. (2017). Invitation to human communication (2nd ed.). Cengage Learning.

(2) Journal articles
• Burgener, A. M. (2020). Enhancing communication to improve patient safety and to increase patient satisfaction. The Health Care Manager, 39(3), 128-132. https://doi: 10.1097/HCM.0000000000000298
https://doi: 10.1097/HCM.0000000000000298
• Foronda, C., MacWilliams, B., & McArthur, E. (2016). Interprofessional communication in healthcare: An integrative review. Nurse Education in Practice, 19, 36-40. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nepr.2016.04.005
• Laughey, W., Sangvik Grandal, N., Stockbridge, C., & Finn, G. M. (2019). Twelve tips for teaching empathy using simulated patients. Medical Teacher, 41(8), 883-887. https://doi.org/10.1080/0142159X.2018.1481283
• Bodenheimer, T. (2018). Teach-back: a simple technique to enhance patients’ understanding. Family Practice Management, 25(4), 20-22.

courses.subject: MEDF
courses.title: Interprofessional Healthcare I
courses.description: Students will learn about interprofessional collaboration and teamwork in the healthcare setting and foundational knowledge including effective communication skills among peers and patients. Besides, students will learn a variety of essential clinical skills including basic life support, aseptic technique and vital signs.
courses.component:
Laboratory
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
Workshop
courses.learning_outcomes:
| By the end of this course, students should be able to: * describe interprofessional collaboration and why it is important; * describe and differentiate healthcare roles and provision in hospitals and community in Hong Kong; * describe and differentiation different responsibilities of the healthcare professional team; * describe a patient illness journey and identify the complexities of issues encountered by patients relating to health conditions and healthcare provision; * demonstrate professionalism and interprofessional collaboration; * develop effective communication skills and apply the skills to care for individuals; * understand principles and knowledge underlying the performance of clinical skills and related assessment; and * demonstrate level of competency in clinical skills including basic life support, aseptic technique and vital signs using a clinical scenario in the laboratory setting. |
| --- |
courses.course_syllabus:
| 1) Professionalism, Patient Complexity and Care 2) Foundations in Clinical Skills I 2.1 Peer and patient communications skills 2.2 Basic life support 2.3 Aseptic technique 2.4 Vital signs 3) Essential Search Skills - Virtual medical library tour |
| --- |

courses.description: Students will learn in interprofessional teams on key healthcare topics such as biomedical ethics, global health, artificial intelligence, professionalism, medical humanities and sociology. Guided team discussions on case scenarios will explore deeper learning of ethics and artificial intelligence. Community visits and experience learning aim to enhance students’ understanding of medical humanities and sociology. In additional, students will learn about vaccinations and demonstrate basic clinical skills of intramuscular and subcutaneous injections. Students are exposed to and discuss these concepts in English, through which their English communication skills are trained.
courses.component:
Discussion
Laboratory
Lecture
Interactive Tutorial
Visit
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Public health and healthcare ethics
1. 1 Public Health and Healthcare Ethics:
• Foundation Concepts of Public Health
• Health Systems in Hong Kong
• Biomedical Ethics in Healthcare Settings - Principlism
• Ethics discussion – team-based learning
1. 2 Artificial Intelligence (AI) Ethics in Medicine and Professionalism
• Professionalism in Medicine and Healthcare
• AI Ethics in Medicine

2) Medical humanities and sociology
• Medical Humanities & sociology
• External visits e.g. Hong Kong Museum of Medical Sciences香港醫學博物館 and others.

3) Foundations in Clinical Skills II
• Intramuscular and subcutaneous injections

courses.subject: MEDF
courses.title: Public Health
courses.description: This course will introduce undergraduate students to healthcare issues and challenges facing our society in the 21st century. The study of public health will include history of modern medicine and public health to current global health issues including infectious disease & pandemics, non-communicable diseases, air pollution and policy making. Introduction to data, research and evidence base will encompass data interpretations and study designs, bias and misinformation to equip students with the basics in finding and critically analysing information and in presenting information in public health topic and oral presentation
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For MBChB Major
Not for students who have taken UGEC1920 or PHPC1001
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:
1. describe public health domains and social determinants of health
2. understand the scope of public health with illustrated examples in infectious disease, environmental health and non-communicable diseases
3. understand the use of data, research and evidence base in policy making and its complexities; and
4. work collaboratively on topical public health issues and in presenting in a conference public health topic presentation (poster)
courses.course_syllabus:
- Course Introduction: An introduction to public health
- Social determinants and health inequity
- Public Health & healthcare system in Hong Kong
- Lifestyle and non-communicable diseases
- Infectious disease and pandemics
- Environmental health
- Population and health data
- Research, health studies and evidence base
- Tutorials & poster presentation
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of each subject.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussions with the class representatives.
courses.recommended_readings:
Reference
- Griffiths S, Hill A, Gillian S. Public Health and Primary Care, New York, USA: Oxford University Press; 2007
- Schneider M-J. Introduction to Public Health (5th edition) 2017. Jones and Bartlett Publishers; Massachusetts.
- An introduction to medical statistics (Reprint 3rd edition) Martin Bland. ISBN-13: 978-0199589920
- Guest G & Namey E. Public Health Research Methods. 2015. Available as e-book at: https://methods-sagepub-com.easyaccess1.lib.cuhk.edu.hk/book/public-health-research-methods
- John E. Havel, Raymond E. Hampton, Scott J. Meiners. Introductory Biological Statistics (4th Edition) 2019. Waveland Press, Inc.. ISBN 13: 978-1-4786-3818-6

Suggested books on hold in library:
- Kuhnke E. Communication Skills for dummies. 2013. John Wiley & Sons Ltd. Available as e-book at CUHK library
